feed.title: NewsTracker: baltimore
feed.subtitle: This is a news tracking demo

entry.title: Peaceful Baltimore demonstrators praise top prosecutor
entry.summary: "I think it has to do with Ms. Mosby living here in West Baltimore: they took seriously the sentiment of the youth," said Kustanya McCray, a 41-year-old Baltimore resident who joined thousands of people at the demonstration.

entry.title: Peaceful Baltimore demonstrators praise top prosecutor
entry.summary: Desmera Gatewood, 24, (front) protests through downtown Durham, N.C. in solidarity with Baltimore demonstrators on Friday, May 1, 2015.

entry.title: Peaceful Baltimore demonstrators praise top prosecutor
entry.summary: J.R. White, right, takes a selfie in front of a mural that was painted at the site of Freddie Gray's arrest, Saturday, May 2, 2015, in Baltimore, as protesters prepare to march to City Hall.

entry.title: Experts: Convictions Will Be Tough to Win in Baltimore Case
entry.summary: "That's really the sort of shocking charge," said Andrew Alperstein, a Baltimore defense attorney and former prosecutor.

entry.title: Experts: Convictions will be tough to win in Baltimore case
entry.summary: Even in Baltimore city, where juries tend to be skeptical of police officers, they can still make compelling defendants and persuasive witnesses, said Ivey, who is currently a candidate for Congress in Maryland's Washington suburbs.

entry.title: Experts: Convictions will be tough to win in Baltimore case
entry.summary:
However, the prosecutor steered clear of specifically alleging Goodson took Mosely on a "Rough Ride," the term commonly applied in Baltimore to the practice of the driver making quick stops and sharp turns so as to slam the prisoner around in the back of the van.

Andrew Levy, a longtime Baltimore defense attorney and adjunct professor at the University of Maryland School of Law, said lawyers could argue that their individual clients cannot be held responsible for Gray's death.

entry.title: Experts: Convictions Will Be Tough to Win in Baltimore Case
entry.summary: Baltimore's top prosecutor acted swiftly, charging six officers in the death of Freddie Gray, who suffered a grave spinal injury as he was arrested and put into a police transport van, handcuffed and without a seat belt.

entry.title: Stars speak out about Baltimore; others won't risk it
entry.summary: Some of the celebrity voices heard in the wake of the Baltimore unrest have been simple pleas for peace, and from stars with direct connections to the issue.

entry.title: Some stars are speaking out about Baltimore, but at what risk, to what effect?
entry.summary: LOS ANGELES - As the events in Baltimore continue to grip the nation, a few celebrities are raising their voices for the city and the cause.

entry.title: Stars speak out about Baltimore; others won't risk it
entry.summary: Former Baltimore Ravens linebacker Ray Lewis and New York Knicks star Carmelo Anthony, who was raised in Baltimore, marched with the protesters this week.

entry.title: The Latest: Baltimore Police Officers Face Hearing May 27
entry.summary: Heavily armed police and National Guard troops are making a show of force at key intersections and government buildings in Baltimore in preparation for Saturday's mass protest marches.

entry.title: Baltimore heads into weekend of rallies after officers charged
Problems facing the poor inch into 2016 presidential race amid tensions in Baltimore
entry.summary: A frustrated President Barack Obama challenged the nation to do "some soul-searching" after riots in Baltimore followed the death of 25-year-old Freddie Gray in police custody.

entry.title: Thousands expected in Baltimore rallies, now celebratory
entry.summary: Demonstrators walk down Mangum Street toward the Durham County Detention Center while protesting in solidarity with Baltimore demonstrators, Friday, May 1, 2015, in Durham, N.C. Hundreds took part in the peaceful protest that began at the Durham Police headquarters and ended at the Durham County Detention Center.

entry.title: Across country, police scrutinized after Baltimore arrests
entry.summary: A message reading "All Lives Matter" is written on the pavement as police in riot gear cast shadows while standing in line ahead of a curfew Friday, May 1, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Thousands expected in Baltimore rallies, now celebratory
entry.summary: The family lawyer, Billy Murphy, said the charges are "a first step but not the last," adding that Baltimore now has an opportunity to set an example for cities across the nation grappling with police brutality.

entry.title: Prosecutor tracks Baltimore police arrest of Freddie Gray
entry.summary: (Reuters) - Six Baltimore police officers were charged on Friday in the arrest and death in April of a 25-year-old black man, Freddie Gray, the latest flashpoint in police use of lethal force and race relations in the United States.

entry.title: Latest on Baltimore protests: Thousands march across US
entry.summary: About 1,000 protesters decrying police brutality have marched in downtown New York at a May Day rally that took on a new message amid national outrage over a Baltimore man's death in police custody.

entry.title: Six Baltimore officers charged in death of Freddie Gray
entry.summary:
"To the people of Baltimore and the demonstrators across America, I heard your call for 'no justice, no peace.' Your peace is sincerely needed as I work to deliver justice on behalf of this young man," Mosby said at a news conference that quickly changed the tone in the city.

While the charges brought joy and relief to the city of 620,000, residents cautioned that they needed to see justice served, not only in Baltimore but in other poor communities where young black men believe they are targeted by police.

entry.title: Latest on Baltimore protests: Thousands march across US
entry.summary: Seventy-three-year-old activist Richard Malmin says he participates every year but that this rally is bigger due to the death of Freddie Gray, whose spine was severed while in Baltimore police custody last month.

entry.title: Orioles play home games in Florida after riots in Baltimore
entry.summary:
But the attire is appropriate this weekend with Baltimore "hosting" the relocated three-game series in Florida.

Baltimore infielder Steve Pearce, from nearby Lakeland, Florida., not only is playing the unusual home game, but is making his pro debut at second base.

entry.title: Orioles Play Home Games in Florida After Riots in Baltimore
Baltimore prosecutor learned life's lessons in Boston 'police house'
entry.summary: Mosby, who took office only in January, stole the spotlight on Friday with her surprisingly swift decision to criminally charge six Baltimore police officers in the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man.

entry.title: Rage to Relief in Baltimore as 6 Officers Charged in Death
entry.summary: Rage turned to relief in Baltimore Friday when the city's top prosecutor charged six police officers with felonies ranging from assault to murder in the death of Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Republican presidential candidate Rand Paul regrets how Baltimore comment was taken
entry.summary: Paul told radio host Laura Ingraham that he had traveled through Baltimore by train on the night riots broke out following the death of an African-American man in police custody and that he was glad the train did not stop.

entry.title: Baltimore police union defends 6 cops charged in Freddie Gray death
entry.summary: Mosby said she comes from five generations of police officers, that she respects and honors how police serve the people, and that this case should in no way damage the relationship between police and prosecutors in Baltimore.

entry.title: 6 Baltimore officers charged in Freddie Gray's death
entry.summary: Whoops, cheers and shouts of "Justice!" erupted on the steps of the War Memorial Building, and in the streets of Baltimore, which has faced nearly two weeks of growing anger over Gray's death.

entry.title: Baltimore police officers charged in death of Freddie Gray [Video]
entry.summary: BALTIMORE - Six Baltimore police officers have been charged, including one with murder, in the death of a black man who was arrested and suffered a fatal neck injury while riding in a moving police van, the city's chief prosecutor said on Friday.

entry.title: Jeb Bush on Baltimore police charges: 'The process works'
entry.summary: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) - Former Florida Gov. Jeb Bush says he trusts the legal process that resulted in charges against six Baltimore officers in the death of a man from injuries sustained while in police custody.

entry.title: 6 Baltimore officers charged in Freddie Gray's death
entry.summary: Marilyn Mosby, Baltimore state's attorney, pauses while speaking during a media availability, Friday, May 1, 2015 in Baltimore.

entry.title: Freddie Gray case: Six Baltimore police officers face murder, false imprisonment charges in death of black man
entry.summary: Marilyn Mosby, the state's attorney for Baltimore City, said Gray, who died a week after his April 12 arrest, suffered a critical neck injury as a result of being handcuffed inside the van.

entry.title: Latest on police-custody death: Union defends 6 officers
entry.summary: Fraternal Order of Police Lodge 3 President Gene Ryan made the comment Friday in a letter to Baltimore City State's Attorney Marilyn Mosby before she announced the charges.

entry.title: State's Attorney: Death of Freddie Gray ruled homicide; 6 officers charged
entry.summary: The Baltimore state's attorney says the death of Freddie Gray has been ruled a homicide.

entry.title: Police union: 6 officers aren't responsible for Freddie Gray's death, were diligent in case
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Police union: 6 officers aren't responsible for Freddie Gray's death, were diligent in case.

entry.title: Scant Details From Gray Death as Baltimore Protests Continue
entry.summary: She swiftly rejected a request from the Baltimore police officers union asking her to appoint a special independent prosecutor because of her ties to attorney Billy Murphy, who is representing Gray's family.

entry.title: Scant details from Gray death as Baltimore protests continue
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Baltimore's top prosecutor announced criminal charges Friday against all six officers suspended after a man suffered a fatal spinal injury in police custody, saying "no one is above the law."

entry.title: Baltimore's prosecutor faces big test 4 months into job
Scant details from Gray death as Baltimore protests continue
entry.summary: Members of the Baltimore Police Department wait for curfew to begin for the third night, Thursday, April 30, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Baltimore's prosecutor faces big test 4 months into job
entry.summary: Brown and Ivan Bates, a former prosecutor and a current defense attorney in Baltimore, both expressed concerns about Mosby's ties to the attorney representing Gray's family, Billy Murphy.

entry.title: Baltimore's Prosecutor Faces Big Test 4 Months Into Job
entry.summary: Mosby and her husband, a Baltimore city councilman, are black and live just blocks from the poverty-stricken community where riots broke out Monday following Gray's funeral.

entry.title: Baltimore's prosecutor faces big test 4 months into job
entry.summary: Baltimore's chief prosecutor is 35 years old, has been on the job for less than four months, and is about to take on the biggest challenge of her career weighing the evidence against six police officers in the death of Freddie Gray and deciding whether they deserve to be criminally charged.

entry.title: Records show worries over mental stability of Baltimore officer suspended in fatal incident
entry.summary: Baltimore police were made aware of worries that Rice might pose a risk to himself or others, according to the April 2012 sheriff's report.

entry.title: Scant details from Gray death as Baltimore protests continue
entry.summary: The secrecy may be legally appropriate, but many in Baltimore were finding it hard to be patient Thursday when police revealed next to nothing about the criminal investigation they turned over to the state's attorney's office.

entry.title: Scant details from Gray death as Baltimore protests continue
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE (AP) - Authorities' refusal to provide more than a few sketchy details about the Freddie Gray investigation is fueling suspicion and mistrust as a weekend of protest rallies looms.

Protesters were planning large demonstrations in Baltimore and around the country Friday, which is May Day, a date traditionally used to champion labor issues but which has expanded over the years to include such causes as women's and immigrant rights.

entry.title: A barber's half-century of clipping hair in a changing Baltimore
entry.summary: Lenny Clay stands outside his barbershop in Baltimore, Maryland April 29, 2015.

entry.title: Baltimore officials ask for patience in probe of black man's death
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE - As protesters marched in several cities, Baltimore officials asked for patience on Thursday while prosecutors decide whether to charge six officers involved in the arrest of a black man who later died of injuries he sustained while in custody.

"I think it's unfortunate that these little things are coming out... People should take a deep breath and wait for the state's attorney to come out with the entire information," Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts told CNN.

entry.title: Police findings on Baltimore man's death handed to prosecutors
entry.summary: After demonstrations and a night of rioting in Baltimore, protests spread to other major cities on Wednesday, a reprise of demonstrations last year set off by police killings of unarmed black men in Ferguson, Missouri; New York; and elsewhere.

entry.title: Harbaugh, Lewis, Ravens Visit Schools in Riot-Torn Baltimore
entry.summary: "There were some hard questions. The young people of Frederick Douglass, the elementary school we went to, even people on the street walking back and forth, these are talented, good people that care about Baltimore and want to make a difference and do things right."

entry.title: Harbaugh, Lewis, Ravens visit schools in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary: Former Baltimore Ravens NFL football player Ray Lewis talks to students at Frederick Douglass High School as Ravens C.J. Mosley looks on Thursday, April 30, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Baltimore riot damage adds burden to small businesses
entry.summary:
Korean-Americans were particularly hard-hit: They run many small businesses in black neighborhoods in Baltimore, and there have been tensions between owners and residents.

She said the company doesn't yet have a damage estimate to share, but said "we have a long history of serving inner-city communities and we remain committed to serving our patients and customers in Baltimore."

entry.title: Police: Half of Those Arrested During Riots Released
entry.summary: Baltimore police say more than half of the people detained during Monday's riots have been released without charges.

entry.title: Small businesses hurt by Baltimore riot face recovery hurdles, even with government help
entry.summary: His West Baltimore liquor store and bar, the Oxford Tavern, was hit by looters during a riot over the police-involved death of neighborhood resident Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Harbaugh, Lewis, Ravens visit schools in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary: Ravens coach John Harbaugh, his players and former star linebacker Ray Lewis visited Baltimore schools to help quell tension in the city following days of rioting.

entry.title: Baltimore police give prosecutors report on Freddie Gray's death
entry.summary: Police have said there were no plans to make the findings public, but the report was turned over to Baltimore City's chief prosecutor a day earlier than expected, Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts told a news conference.

entry.title: Baltimore police hand report on Gray death to prosecutor
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Baltimore police have completed their investigation into the death of Freddie Gray and turned over their findings to prosecutors - one day earlier than the department's self-imposed deadline, the commissioner said Thursday morning.

entry.title: Baltimore police give findings into Freddie Gray death to prosecutor
More than 100 arrested in Baltimore overnight
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE - Residents of Baltimore and activists across the United States waited on Thursday for official word on the cause of a black man's death in police custody earlier this month, as protests over the case spread to other cities.

Baltimore officials tried to tamp down expectations that there would be a quick answer on the fate of the six police officers involved in the arrest that preceded Gray's death.

entry.title: Baltimore officials: No immediate decision in Gray case
entry.summary: Police in riot gear walk past boarded up row homes after a 10 p.m. curfew went into effect Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Baltimore death sparks protests in New York, Boston, Philly
entry.summary: The march and a rally, held in support of Baltimore protesters angered by the death of a black man in police custody, was organized by Mass Action Against Police Brutality.

entry.title: Baltimore Officials: No Immediate Decision in Gray Case
entry.summary:
Both Rawlings-Blake and Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts spent much of the day Wednesday trying to explain that no final resolution to the case would come Friday.

But widespread protests Wednesday night - not only in Baltimore, but in several cities including Boston, New York and Washington, D.C. - made it clear that tensions over the case are far from subsiding.

entry.title: Rioting prompts state of emergency declaration in Baltimore
entry.summary: "People have the right to protest and express their frustration. But Baltimore city families deserve peace and safety in their communities. And these acts of violence and destruction cannot and will not be tolerated."

entry.title: Obama aide, Baltimore native says worst may be over
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (AP) - The leader of President Barack Obama's initiative for minority males says it has been painful to watch violence and looting unfold in his Baltimore hometown, but he feels optimistic that the worst is over.

entry.title: Baltimore death sparks protests in New York, Boston, Philly
entry.summary:
Nikea Ramsey, whose brother, Burrell Ramsey-White, was shot and killed in an encounter with Boston police in 2012, said, "Me and my family, we stand with Baltimore. We stand with Ferguson. This is too much and it's getting out of hand."

In Philadelphia, protesters plan to conduct the "Philly is Baltimore" demonstration Thursday afternoon at city hall.

entry.title: Baltimore death sparks protests in New York, Boston, Philly
entry.summary: NEW YORK (AP) - Hundreds of people have rallied and marched in New York and Boston to protest the death of a Baltimore man who was critically injured in police custody as Philadelphia activists prepare for their own demonstration.

entry.title: Right call? Orioles take the field in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary: Baltimore Orioles' Everth Cabrera, bottom center, runs toward first base as he doubles in the first inning of a baseball game against the Chicago White Sox, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Latest on police-custody death: Protesters gather in Houston
entry.summary: More than a dozen people have been arrested at a rally in Manhattan's Union Square to protest the death of Freddie Gray, a Baltimore man who was critically injured in police custody.

entry.title: Latest on police-custody death: Protesters gather in Houston
entry.summary: A group of protesters stretching more than a block has left Penn Station in Baltimore for a march to City Hall to protest Freddie Gray's death after being hurt while in police custody.

entry.title: Marchers protest police violence in Baltimore, New York
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (Reuters) - Protesters marched against police violence in cities from New York to Boston on Wednesday, as troops stood by in Baltimore to enforce a curfew imposed after civil unrest over the death of a 25-year-old black man.

entry.title: Thousands in other cities protest death of Baltimore man
entry.summary: Protestors demonstrate outside the State Attorney's office calling for the continued investigation into the death of Freddie Gray, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Right call? Orioles take the field in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary: The game was played in an empty Oriole Park at Camden Yards amid unrest in Baltimore over the death of Freddie Gray at the hands of police.

entry.title: Right call? Orioles take the field in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary: Baltimore Orioles right fielder Delmon Young fields a single by Chicago White Sox's Avisail Garcia in the second inning of a baseball game, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Station suspends DJ over posting on arrest record of Baltimore man fatally injured in custody
entry.summary: PITTSBURGH - A Pittsburgh radio station has suspended a disc jockey over his online posting about the arrest record of a Baltimore man whose fatal injury in police custody led to rioting.

entry.title: Baltimore finds fragile calm while awaiting answers to man's death
entry.summary: Baltimore's Major League Baseball team, the Orioles, played the Chicago White Sox in an empty stadium, a sign of the tenuous security situation.

entry.title: At Empty Camden Yards, Orioles Beat White Sox 8-2
entry.summary: The gates at Camden Yards were locked because of concern for fan safety following recent rioting in Baltimore after a 25-year-old black man died in police custody.

entry.title: Right call? Orioles take the field in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary: Chicago White Sox catcher Tyler Flowers sits in the dugout of an empty stadium before playing the Baltimore Orioles in a baseball game, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Right Call? Orioles Take the Field in Riot-Torn Baltimore
entry.summary: The team didn't divert any police from doing their job around the city, but the people of Baltimore didn't get a chance to turn the page by watching the home team play at Camden Yards.

entry.title: Right call? Orioles take the field in riot-torn Baltimore
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE (AP) - With rubble and debris looming nearby, and tempers still smoldering in riot-torn Baltimore, the Orioles played a baseball game on Wednesday.

In Baltimore, after a drug store was set on fire about four miles from the ballpark and the National Guard was summoned to restore order, they played a game because this was the only planned visit by this season by the Chicago White Sox.

entry.title: A look at the knowns and unknowns in the Baltimore case
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - A week and a half after 25-year-old Freddie Gray died, there are still many unanswered questions about the explosive case.

entry.title: A game with no fans: Should Orioles, White Sox have played?
entry.summary: Baltimore Orioles starting pitcher Ubaldo Jimenez throws to Chicago White Sox's Adam Eaton in the first inning of a baseball game, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Tensions ease in Baltimore as curfew lifts, schools reopen
entry.summary: Broken store windows remain as members of the Anne Arundel County Police stand guard at the intersection of North Avenue and Pennsylvania Avenue, Wednesday, April 29, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Clinton: Baltimore shows justice system 'out of balance'
entry.summary: Pointing to a wave of violence in Baltimore, Hillary Rodham Clinton said Wednesday that the nation's criminal justice system has gotten "out of balance" and must be restored through steps such as the use of body cameras by every police department in the country.

entry.title: Clinton: Baltimore shows justice system 'out of balance'
entry.summary: Clinton spoke in the days after violence and protests have swept through the streets of Baltimore following the death of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who suffered a spinal-cord injury while in police custody.

entry.title: Schools reopen in Baltimore, streets quiet after curfew
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Schools reopened across the city and tensions seemed to ease Wednesday after Baltimore made it through the first night of its curfew without the widespread violence many had feared.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet after curfew
entry.summary: Police advance through a cloud of tear gas as they enforce curfew, Tuesday, April 28, 2015, in Baltimore, a day after unrest that occurred following Freddie Gray's funeral.

entry.title: Baltimore curfew ends with streets quiet, nearly empty
entry.summary: In an interview broadcast Wednesday on "The Steve Harvey Morning Show," President Barack Obama said the Baltimore riots show that police departments need to build more trust in black communities.

entry.title: Baltimore riots force 2nd postponed game between Orioles, White Sox
entry.summary: After a pair of postponements caused by rioting in Baltimore, the Orioles and Chicago White Sox will play Wednesday at Camden Yards in what is believed to be the first game without fans in Major League Baseball's history.

entry.title: Latest on police-custody death: Curfew
entry.summary: At midnight Tuesday, Baltimore police arrested one man wearing a Wu-Tang Clan T-shirt for violating the 10 p.m. curfew near the scene of Tuesday night's demonstration.

entry.title: Baltimore calm after some trouble as curfew began
entry.summary: But the rioting also brought out a sense of civic pride and responsibility in many Baltimore residents, with hundreds of volunteers turning out to sweep the streets of glass and other debris with brooms and trash bags donated by hardware stores.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary: Volunteers clean a CVS pharmacy Tuesday, April 28, 2015, in Baltimore, in the aftermath of rioting following Monday's funeral for Freddie Gray, who died in police custody.

entry.title: Baltimore streets quiet under curfew
entry.summary: Baltimore Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake, left, speaks as Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts, centre, listens, during a news conference, in Baltimore, Tuesday, April 28, 2015.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary: But as part of the state of emergency, the governor extended the period to no later than 47 hours, according to a letter he sent Tuesday to Judge Barbara Baer Waxman, the administrative judge for the Baltimore District Court.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary:
The clash came after a day of high tension but relative peace in Baltimore, which was rocked by looting and widespread arson Monday in the city's worst outbreak of rioting since 1968.

Just before midnight Tuesday, Baltimore Police Commissioner Anthony Batts declared the curfew, which ends at 5 a.m., a success.

entry.title: Baltimore streets once rocked by riots quiet under curfew
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Baltimore streets previously rocked by riots were eerily quiet early Wednesday as residents obeyed an all-night curfew enforced by 3,000 police and National Guardsmen.

entry.title: Police say curfew in riot-hit Baltimore working
entry.summary: But he warned that incidents in recent months "raise troubling questions" about the policing of black communities in the United States.

entry.title: Police enforce curfew in Baltimore, disperse protesters
Police clash with Baltimore protesters for a second night
entry.summary: Mayor Stephanie Rawlings-Blake waited hours to ask the governor to declare a state of emergency, and the governor hinted she should have come to him earlier.

entry.title: Riot-hit Baltimore, an American city divided by income and opportunity
entry.summary: By comparison, across the whole of the U.S., the top take in $9.30 for every dollar earned at the bottom.

entry.title: 'Mum of the year': Baltimore mother filmed hitting and berating her son during riots
entry.summary: "That's my only son and at the end of the day I don't want him to be a Freddie Gray," Graham said.

entry.title: Thousands of police descend on Baltimore to enforce curfew after riots
entry.summary: Schools were closed on Tuesday, but were scheduled to reopen on Wednesday.

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore the product of anger, deep dysfunction
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - Baltimore is crab cakes, the cobblestone walkways of Fells Point, a vintage baseball stadium, the retro weirdness of John Waters.

entry.title: Watch: National Guard Meets Calmer Crowds Tuesday in Baltimore
entry.summary: Make certain that you have these National Guard troops.

entry.title: The Wire creator David Simon condemns 'selfish' Baltimore rioters
entry.summary: "If you can’t seek redress and demand reform without a brick in your hand, you risk losing this moment for all of us in Baltimore. Turn around. Go home. Please."

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore raise questions about police response
entry.summary: A man rides a bicycle through heavy smoke that is emitting from a nearby store on fire, Monday, April 27, 2015, during unrest following the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

entry.title: Baltimore riot: Fires, chaos, National Guard after Freddie Gray funeral
entry.summary: The violence, which began in West Baltimore -- within a mile of where Freddie Gray was arrested and pushed into a police van earlier this month -- had by the end of the day spread to East Baltimore and neighborhoods close to downtown and near the baseball stadium.

entry.title: Baltimore mayor says outsiders turned peaceful protest violent
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (Reuters) - Baltimore's mayor and police on Sunday again blamed outside agitators for violence and vandalism that flared during a mostly peaceful protest over last week's death of a young black man who sustained an unexplained spinal injury while under arrest.

entry.title: Baltimore deploys Guard troops as riots erupt
entry.summary: Thousands of police and National Guard troopers were ordered to back up beleaguered officers in Baltimore on Tuesday after riots triggered by anger over the death of a black man in police custody.

entry.title: Baltimore racked by violence; governor calls out National Guard
entry.summary: Rioters in the streets of Baltimore are looting stores.

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore over man's death in police custody
entry.summary: A brick sits on a street as police standby, Monday, April 27, 2015, during a skirmish with demonstrators after the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

entry.title: Riots in Baltimore over man's death in police custody
entry.summary:
Firefighters battle a blaze, Monday, April 27, 2015, after rioters plunged part of Baltimore into chaos, torching a pharmacy, setting police cars ablaze and throwing bricks at officers.

Residents watch as Baltimore police officers clash with protesters in the streets near Mondawmin Mall April 27, 2015 in Baltimore, Maryland.

A mourner embraces Gloria Darden, left, mother of Freddie Gray, before Gray's funeral, Monday, April 27, 2015, at New Shiloh Baptist Church in Baltimore.

entry.title: Riot, looting prompt state of emergency, curfew in Baltimore
entry.summary: Rep. Elijah Cummings, D-Md., addresses mourners at a funeral for Freddie Gray, Monday, April 27, 2015, at New Shiloh Baptist Church in Baltimore.

entry.title: AP PHOTOS: Riots Hit Baltimore After Freddie Gray Funeral
entry.summary: Rioting erupted in Baltimore on Monday evening, following the funeral of the black man who died in police custody after suffering a severe spinal cord injury.

entry.title: AP PHOTOS: Riots hit Baltimore after Freddie Gray funeral
entry.summary:
A demonstrator taunts police as they respond to thrown objects, Monday, April 27, 2015, after the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

EDS NOTE: OBSCENE GESTURES - People stand on top of a Baltimore police car in Baltimore on Monday, April 27, 2015, during unrest following the funeral of Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Baltimore erupts in riots after funeral of man who died in police custody
entry.summary: The riots broke out just a few blocks from the funeral of Freddie Gray and then spread through much of West Baltimore in the most violent U.S. demonstrations since arson and shooting in Ferguson, Missouri, last year.

entry.title: Maryland governor declares state of emergency over Baltimore violence
entry.summary: April 27 (Reuters) - Maryland Governor Larry Hogan declared a state of emergency and activated the National Guard to address the violence in Baltimore, his office said on Monday.

entry.title: Baltimore erupts in riots after funeral of man who died in police custody [Photos]
entry.summary: Protesters hurled bricks, looted businesses and set fires in Baltimore on Monday in violence that injured at least seven police officers following the funeral of a 25-year-old black man who died after he was injured in police custody.

entry.title: Maryland governor declares state of emergency in Baltimore over rioting
entry.summary: A man carries items from a store as police vehicles burn after the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore on Monday.

entry.title: Obama pledges help for Baltimore riots after Gray funeral
entry.summary: WASHINGTON (AP) - President Barack Obama is pledging the federal government's help to respond to riots that have broken out in Baltimore following the funeral of Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Orioles' game in Baltimore postponed due to safety concerns (Yahoo Sports)
entry.summary: Rioters looted stores and threw rocks and bricks at Baltimore police about three miles from the stadium in the wake of the mysterious death of Gray.

entry.title: State of Emergency Declared Amid Violent Clashes in Baltimore
entry.summary: A man walks past a burning police vehicle, April 27, 2015, during unrest following the funeral of Freddie Gray in Baltimore.

entry.title: Riots erupt in Baltimore after Freddie Gray funeral
entry.summary: Baltimore police initially showed restraint on Monday but then began arresting people and prepared to use teargas and pepper spray.

entry.title: Baltimore clashes: violence flares after Freddie Gray's funeral
entry.summary:
Seven Baltimore police officers were injured on Monday as rioters threw bricks and stones and burned patrol cars in violent protests after the funeral of a black man who died in police custody.

The riots broke out just a few blocks from the site of the funeral of 25-year-old Freddie Gray in northwest Baltimore and then spread through other parts of the city, after local law enforcement warned of a threat by gangs.

Baltimore Police Captain Eric Kowalczyk said at a police briefing that one of the injured police officers was unresponsive and several had broken bones.

entry.title: US diplomat recalls racial tension in Baltimore
entry.summary:
A U.S. diplomat opened her speech on Iranian nuclear negotiations talking about how she grew up going to civil rights marches and says her father once helped baseball star Frank Robinson find a home in an all-white neighborhood of Baltimore.

The recent case of Freddie Gray, a 25-year-old black man who died after sustaining serious injuries while in the custody of Baltimore police, has intensified a national debate over police treatment of African-Americans.

entry.title: Barack Obama to send aide to Freddie Gray funeral in Baltimore on Monday
entry.summary: The White House says the head of President Barack Obama's initiative for minority males will attend the funeral of a Baltimore man who died after sustaining serious injuries while in police custody.

entry.title: Thousands expected to attend Freddie Gray's funeral in Baltimore - Dozens arrested as Freddie Gray protests turn violent in Baltimore - VIDEO: Cops: Gray wasn't buckled into seatbelt
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE - Thousands were expected Monday at a funeral for a man who died after sustaining serious spinal injuries while in the custody of Baltimore police.

Pastor Jamal Bryant, who was to deliver Gray's eulogy, said he expected Baltimore's New Shiloh Baptist Church to be filled for the service.

entry.title: Thousands expected to attend Freddie Gray's funeral in Baltimore - Dozens arrested as Freddie Gray protests turn violent in Baltimore - VIDEO: Cops: Gray wasn't buckled into seatbelt
entry.summary: Broderick Johnson, chairman of the My Brother's Keeper Task Force and a Baltimore native, is to be joined by two other administration officials, a White House statement said.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary:
The body of Freddie Gray lies inside his casket at Vaughn Greene Funeral Home, during his wake Sunday, April 26, 2015 in Baltimore.

Caira Byrd hold support signs for Freddie Gray outside of Vaughn Greene Funeral Home, during his wake in Baltimore, Md., Sunday, April 26, 2015.

A child accepts a gift of a bag of chips from a police officer outside the Western District before a march to City Hall for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015 in Baltimore.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary:
Fans fill the aisles in the ballpark after being told not to leave for their own safety during the Baltimore Orioles and the Boston Red Sox baseball game, Saturday, April 25, 2015, in Baltimore.

Fredricka Gray, center, the twin sister of Freddie Gray, speaks during a media availability at City Hall, after violence occurred after a march for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015 in Baltimore.

A protestor reacts after breaking a restaurant window after a rally for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015, in Baltimore.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary:
A night of violence gave way to a day of mourning Sunday for a man who died after sustaining serious injuries while in the custody of Baltimore police.

Police line a street in downtown Baltimore in response to protests that followed a rally for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015.

Police stand in helmets near Pratt Street after a march to City Hall for Freddie Gray, Saturday, April 25, 2015 in Baltimore.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary: Some 34 people were arrested, according to Baltimore Police Department, and six police officers sustained minor injuries.

entry.title: Family, friends in Baltimore mourn death of arrested man
entry.summary: Gray was arrested one week before that when officers chased him through a West Baltimore neighborhood and dragged him into a police van.

entry.title: The Latest: Photographer says police beat him during protest
entry.summary: The women said they knew Baltimore had issues with police before Gray's death.

entry.title: Photographer Says Baltimore Police Beat Him During Protest
entry.summary: J.M. Giordano, who works at the City Paper, says Baltimore police "swarmed over" him and hit him repeatedly.

entry.title: Photographer says Baltimore police beat him during protest
entry.summary: BALTIMORE (AP) - A photo editor for a Baltimore newspaper says he was beaten by police at a protest over the death of Freddie Gray.

entry.title: Former Baltimore Raven Ray Lewis sues attorney over failed MVP Lanes development project
entry.summary:
BALTIMORE - Former Baltimore Ravens star Ray Lewis is suing his former attorney over a failed development project he says cost him $1.5 million.

The suit accuses the Baltimore lawyer of convincing Lewis to sign a $1.5 million line of credit for the project, and later asking for another $200,000.

entry.title: Amazon.com introduces one-hour delivery to Baltimore, Miami
entry.summary: In Miami and Baltimore, Prime Now is available from 8 a.m. to 10 p.m., seven days a week.

entry.title: Amazon.com introduces one-hour delivery to Baltimore, Miami
entry.summary:
NEW YORK (AP) - Amazon.com is expanding its one-hour delivery Prime Now service to Baltimore and Miami.

The company says that the service will be expanded only to certain zip codes within Baltimore and Miami at first, but it plans to further expand within each city soon.

entry.title: Baltimore Ravens RB Pierce charged with drunken driving
entry.summary: Drafted in the third round of the 2002 draft out of Temple, Pierce started three games in three years with Baltimore.

entry.title: Baltimore Ravens running back Bernard Pierce charged with drunken driving
entry.summary: He was released by Baltimore as soon as the investigation began.

entry.title: Baltimore Ravens RB Pierce charged with drunken driving
entry.summary:
This undated handout provided by the Baltimore County Police Department shows Bernard Pierce.

Police in Maryland say Baltimore Ravens running back Bernard Pierce has been charged with drunken driving.

Baltimore County police say an officer stopped a Ford Mustang that was speeding around 2 a.m. Wednesday, March 18, 2015, in Towson, north of Baltimore.

entry.title: Three stabbed at Baltimore's Morgan State University: Report
entry.summary: Three football players at Baltimore's Morgan State University were stabbed on campus on Tuesday and one was seriously injured, the Baltimore Sun reported.

entry.title: Baltimore police say at least 3 stabbed on Morgan State University campus; 1 seriously hurt
entry.summary: It was the third instance of violence on the Baltimore campus in less than a week.

entry.title: Baltimore police say at least 3 people stabbed on Morgan State University campus in Maryland
Police: 1 Stabbed at Morgan State University in Maryland
entry.summary: Baltimore police say one person was stabbed and seriously injured at Morgan State University in Baltimore.

entry.title: High court to hear appeal from Baltimore police officer
Ray Rice Apologizes to Baltimore for 'Horrible Mistake'
entry.summary:
The last seven years that my family and I have spent in Baltimore have by far been the best of our lives.

Thank you, Baltimore Ravens, for all you have done for my family and I.

I love you all very much, and I'll always be proud to say I played for the Baltimore Ravens.
